Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as the site-wide evacuation alarm blared through the air. I froze for a split second, heart pounding. It was Thursday—my day to call Mom and Dad, to reassure them I was safe, to listen to Dad’s stories and Mom’s gentle reminders to eat well. I’d promised I’d never miss a call, not after last winter when Mom got sick and I hadn’t known for days. But now, the foreman’s voice was sharp, echoing over the clamor: “Drop everything! Muster point, now!” My crew was already moving, hard hats bobbing in the crowd. Site protocol was strict—no exceptions, no delays. My phone vibrated again, my parents’ number lighting up the screen. I felt torn, the weight of my promise to my family pressing against the urgent, unyielding rules of the site. My hand hovered over my phone, caught between the need to reassure my parents and the responsibility to my team and my own safety. The alarm wailed, and I stood there, heart racing, pulled in two directions, not knowing which demand to answer first.
